Ampere and ARM?
Done
nit, "users"
Done
what is "none-json"?

Example:
The third application or pldmd can implement the its CPER
decoder to extract the CPER `typeID`, `subtype` and others `context info` to log those info to Ipmitool SEL Log. In this case, the application needs specific data fields in CPER data to log to Ipmi SEL log but not all of CPER in Json format.

Even, if the `pldmd` call the cper-parser to decode the CPER data to
json format, it still needs the definition in the `cper-section*` header
to find the `typeID`, `subtype` fields in the json format depends on the
CPER type.

> Example:
> The third application or pldmd can implement the its CPER
> decoder to extract the CPER `typeID`, `subtype` and others `context info` to log those info to Ipmitool SEL Log. In this case, the application needs specific data fields in CPER data to log to Ipmi SEL log but not all of CPER in Json format.
> 
> Even, if the `pldmd` call the cper-parser to decode the CPER data to
> json format, it still needs the definition in the `cper-section*` header
> to find the `typeID`, `subtype` fields in the json format depends on the
> CPER type.

I'm not following why, if it used json, it would need those header files.  between the json schema and json, it should be able to parse out what's needed into its own structs.

With that said, being able to parse to a struct does seem useful, I would just prefer it not be the structs that exist in the headers.  Things like pragma packed and other things aren't portable between binaries, so if we want to publish a header-interface into libcper, lets make it specific to libcper.

> > Example:
> > The third application or pldmd can implement the its CPER
> > decoder to extract the CPER `typeID`, `subtype` and others `context info` to log those info to Ipmitool SEL Log. In this case, the application needs specific data fields in CPER data to log to Ipmi SEL log but not all of CPER in Json format.
> > 
> > Even, if the `pldmd` call the cper-parser to decode the CPER data to
> > json format, it still needs the definition in the `cper-section*` header
> > to find the `typeID`, `subtype` fields in the json format depends on the
> > CPER type.
> 
> I'm not following why, if it used json, it would need those header files.  between the json schema and json, it should be able to parse out what's needed into its own structs.

Because I think we still need to do some condition checking about the CPER type or CPER field to find the corrected info. Or maybe not.

> 
> With that said, being able to parse to a struct does seem useful, I would just prefer it not be the structs that exist in the headers.  Things like pragma packed and other things aren't portable between binaries, so if we want to publish a header-interface into libcper, lets make it specific to libcper.
Done

These files aren't really intended to be part of the user-facing API.  Can you get some more details on what you're trying to accomplish here, and we can see about adding the appropriate headers for it?

I also worry about only installing some of the headers, without a clear indication as to why these were singled out.  We likely should be doing all or none.

As my understanding, currently, `libcper` is intended to public the `cper-parser` and `cper-generator` user APIs to allow others application call those API to format the CPER data to JSON format or from Json format to CPER data.
I wonder in the case, Ampere wants to log the IPMI SEL log event to identify the typeID, SubType, and some other CPER data to IPMI OEM SEL log how can we achieve that?
[1] https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/73237/11/oem/ampere/event/cper.cpp#57
[2] https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/73237/11/oem/ampere/event/cper.cpp#164
Can you take a look on those codes if I can't explain my idea clearly?

OR

Maybe, Some definitions in `cper_section*` need to be moved to Cper.h to achieve that.

I suspect if we want to publish a header interface, we need to reorganize how our headers are done.  The headers you're trying to publish are the wire format, and are used internally.  Maybe we should just publish the c_json object itself instead of the serialized string?  Then users can look up whatever field they like?

> I suspect if we want to publish a header interface, we need to reorganize how our headers are done.  The headers you're trying to publish are the wire format, and are used internally. 

If the `cper_section*` is intended to be private. Then I agree that we need `reorganize how our headers are done`.

As https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/docs/OEMExtensions.md#creating-a-section-parser
the `sections/cper-section-myvendor.h` will include the `cper_section_myvendor_to_ir` and `ir_section_myvendor_to_cper` APIs.
The other definition are adding in `Cper.h`.

Below `cper-section*` are following that.
https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-firmware.h
https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-memory.h
https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-nvidia.h
https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-pcie.h
https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-ampere.h

But the Arm CPER structs are defined in https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-arm.h
 So I think we have to move Arm definitions to `Cper.h`. What do you think about that?

> Maybe we should just publish the c_json object itself instead of the serialized string?  Then users can look up whatever field they like?

Yes, It is one option too.

> > I suspect if we want to publish a header interface, we need to reorganize how our headers are done.  The headers you're trying to publish are the wire format, and are used internally. 
> 
> If the `cper_section*` is intended to be private. Then I agree that we need `reorganize how our headers are done`.
> 
> As https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/docs/OEMExtensions.md#creating-a-section-parser
> the `sections/cper-section-myvendor.h` will include the `cper_section_myvendor_to_ir` and `ir_section_myvendor_to_cper` APIs.
> The other definition are adding in `Cper.h`.
> 
> Below `cper-section*` are following that.
> https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-firmware.h
> https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-memory.h
> https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-nvidia.h
> https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-pcie.h
> https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-ampere.h
> 
> But the Arm CPER structs are defined in https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-arm.h
>  So I think we have to move Arm definitions to `Cper.h`. What do you think about that?

Yes, that seems to be the issue here.

> 
> > Maybe we should just publish the c_json object itself instead of the serialized string?  Then users can look up whatever field they like?
> 
> Yes, It is one option too.

> > > I suspect if we want to publish a header interface, we need to reorganize how our headers are done.  The headers you're trying to publish are the wire format, and are used internally. 
> > 
> > If the `cper_section*` is intended to be private. Then I agree that we need `reorganize how our headers are done`.
> > 
> > As https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/docs/OEMExtensions.md#creating-a-section-parser
> > the `sections/cper-section-myvendor.h` will include the `cper_section_myvendor_to_ir` and `ir_section_myvendor_to_cper` APIs.
> > The other definition are adding in `Cper.h`.
> > 
> > Below `cper-section*` are following that.
> > https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-firmware.h
> > https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-memory.h
> > https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-nvidia.h
> > https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-pcie.h
> > https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-ampere.h
> > 
> > But the Arm CPER structs are defined in https://github.com/openbmc/libcper/blob/main/sections/cper-section-arm.h
> >  So I think we have to move Arm definitions to `Cper.h`. What do you think about that?
> 
> Yes, that seems to be the issue here.

I updated the patch set to fix the issue.
